header.topics: Physical fitness & health issues, travel plans, punctuality.
header.activity: Two friends talking about various topics (see 9 above) in ANON’s flat in Tarnow, Poland.

speaker.occupation: unemployed/ Some part-time private TEFL teacher/ Semi-retired
Teacher of English as a foreign Language

so when I walk for an hour or more it pulls my kneecap out of alignment so it's all grating and then it hurts but anyway and I had a torn cartilage when I was thirteen

yeah I've got well I used to have cartilage problems but as my kne as my legs I can make them stronger
it seems to be sorting themselves out
a little bit but yeah really common in athletes footballers especially have loads of problems with cartilage in their knees

guy who erm tailors these workout programs for each individual athlete and so you get different types of exercise which obviously aren't suited to everybody because everybody is different
erm and so Arsenal are having fewer injuries and the injuries that they do have recovery is much much faster
erm which I think is magnificent
so it goes to show if you've got the experts that know what they're all about they can sort it out

erm so like the head trainer would come to me and go I've got a new person who's just qualified
will you do a few sessions with them for free?
erm and then you can say what's good what's bad what needs to change

you've got weak wrists you've got weak ankles blah blah blah blah blah
work on this we can work on this do this do this erm and the rest just do you know generic things

I think appearance-based things my personal take on it is where things are the last to manifest so anything that's been going on psychologically spiritually emotionally once you start sorting it on the physical like for example going to the gym or for example not doing your nasal thing that's because the change has already taken place on the inner
so this is like the outer representation of what's already occurred on the inner

no I'm not saying if she's not here in three minutes I'm barring the door she can't come in just reminding you
I don't know why I'm so into time it's sort of social conditioning I think

yeah very possibly I I got broken off that living in Northern Ireland and in England and when I was part of the rat race I used to have breakfast meetings at like seven o' clock or whatever ridiculous time of the morning it was yeah
oh yeah you said this before in Ireland it doesn't work like that

no not at all you have a meeting at ten and if you were there like an English person arriving at ten to ten because you don't want to be late and then at ten o' clock you're still the only person there at ten past ten you're still the only person there and by half past ten everybody's arrived

and you're having coffee and tea and scones cos you have to have scones and it was almost an unspoken rule that while you're drinking tea and eating scones before a meeting you don't talk about the meeting
you talk about yeah everything about family or friendships or what you did at the weekend

and then the meeting will start about eleven so for a ten o' clock meeting don't expect to do anything before eleven but it's quite nice in a way it's a more relaxed lifestyle and if you think oh shit there's a bit of traffic I'm going to be five minutes late you don't need to bother ringing anybody
you don't need to drive like a dick to try and get there all the sooner
we were talking about that this morning er with and about er in Spain and life in Spain and you know? everything is so slow and siestas in the afternoon
and people sort of cancelling last minute cos they just they go oh whatever
ah and I just thought that'd be awful
I think it's going to be kill or cure for you
I'd hate it I'd absolutely hate it but I think it's probably good for me
I used to be quite obsessed with time until I lived in Northern Ireland

and I still drove like an arsehole when I got there and can remember overtaking everything it was possible to overtake on bi bendy country roads on my hour's journey to work every day and then after I probably took about two or three years and I completely chilled out erm even now I don't drive fast and it's fine and I'm not looking at the clock
and it was definitely from Northern Ireland I think had I lived and worked in Belfast or gone down south and lived and worked in Dublin it might have been different
but living rurally working relatively rurally er all change

I don't know how I'm going to cope because I do yeah I never really considered myself to be a sort of control freak person or someone who likes everything to be just so but I think I'm sort of learning that I am that person
erm especially with time er and especially with you know getting things done and being quite not controlling but I like being in control and knowing what's happening
knowing you know the plan or the situation
yeah and having that sort of taken away I don't know how I'll feel
so why are you going to Spain? why are you drawing this experience to you?
really that's the only reason I just need sunshine
yeah yeah I think the siesta thing is quite natural cos you're not going to be working during the hottest part of the day
I suppose in this job you wouldn't be working at that time anyway
if it's I don't know what time it will be one till three or twelve till one or something like that it wouldn't be
it's a few hours though isn't it?
don't you work like seven AM to seven PM and have four hours off or three hours off or something?
